common.text:
### The Genetic Material

When DNA was first discovered, it was named "nuclein", and its true function was uncovered later. In the 20th century, it was renamed "desoxyribonucleic acid" (DNA) and recognized as the molecule responsible for transmitting hereditary information—the foundation of an organism's traits

source.text: Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al.

common.text:
#### Genetic Material Organization

Life is organized hierarchically, from the smallest structures to the largest. Two key molecules enable genetic transmission:
- RNA, a single-stranded nucleotide chain.
- DNA, a double-helix structure

DNARNA
Figure 4: Simplified representation of DNA and RNA. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers Team, )
Inheritance in living beings is governed by chromatin, which condenses into chromosomes during cell division. The location of chromosomes in cells serves as a basis for classifying organisms

- Organisms without a nucleus (prokaryote) have chromosomes composed solely of DNA.
- Organisms with a nucleus (eukaryotic) have DNA bound to proteins.

Reflexión 1: Organización

Si la localización del material genético nos ayuda a clasificar a los seres vivos, ¿podría también revelar relaciones evolutivas entre ellos?

### A Unique People

In this section on Indigenous families, we will explore how Indigenous peoples identified themselves, rather than how they were perceived by people from other continents.

#### When Did They Arrive?

Indigenous peoples were already present in the Americas long before Europeans arrived—first around the year <htdate0> and later in <htdate1>

The exact timing of their migrations remains uncertain, but estimates suggest they occurred between 30,000 and 13,500 years ago. In <htdate0>, José de Acosta proposed that the first Indigenous peoples came from Asia—a hypothesis only confirmed centuries later through research revealing multiple migrations into the region
Figure 5: A map showing Indigenous migration routes across the Bering Strait. Photo taken at the Museo Nacional de Antropología en San Salvador, El Salvador (Museo Nacional de Antrolopogía), on .
common.imgdesc: This image illustrates the various migrations from Asia, with peoples moving from the far north of the continent to the south.

common.text:
#### Genetic Lineage

Anthropological and genetic evidence has been used to determine when Indigenous peoples crossed into North America and their relationship with Asian populations. Various studies have helped map their characteristics and origins, including research by Elena B. Starikovskaya, Matthew C. Dulik, M. Jota, and their teams

Genetic DataDescription
Mitochondrial haplogroupsEarly studies identified haplogroups A, B, C, D, and X in Indigenous mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).
mtDNA A, B, C, and DCommon in Siberian populations and regions near Mongolia.
mtDNA XFound mainly in the Altai Mountains (Russia), near Mongolia, Kazakhstan, and China. It is also found in Europe.
Subhaplogroup A2Most likely originated in the Bering Strait region.
Haplogroup BPresent in Siberia and northern Mongolia.
Haplogroup C (mtDNA)The most common in Siberia.
Diversity of Haplogroup BHighly diversified, with subgroups B1, B3, B4, and B5.
Haplogroups C and DCommon among Altai peoples.
Y ChromosomeMost Indigenous populations have haplogroups C and Q.
Denisovan & Neanderthal DNANo evidence found in Altai mtDNA or Y chromosomes in these studies.
José de Acosta’s hypothesisThe phylogeny of haplogroups A, B, C, and D supports migration via the Bering Strait.
Table 1: Genetic distribution of Indigenous ancestors and their possible origins.

#### What Did Indigenous Peoples Call the Continent?

Not all Indigenous groups developed writing systems, so the names they historically used for the continent cannot always be determined. However, different peoples named their territories—such as *Tawantsuyu*, *Anahahac* and *Pindorama*, many Indigenous communities refer to the continent as Abya Yala, in contrast to "America," a name imposed by colonizers

#### Population Decline

The prosperity of Abya Yala (the Americas) led to significant demographic growth. Current estimates suggest the Indigenous population may have been between 8 and 145 million people. Regardless of the exact number, by <htdate0>, it had plummeted to just 6.5 million

#### Cultural Conflict

Population decline was not the only challenge Indigenous peoples faced in recent centuries. Historical texts written by colonizers and their descendants often reflected a deep misunderstanding of Native cultures, portraying them as inferior. These records were frequently altered—either by "Europeanizing" Indigenous identities, falsifying genealogies to link them to local leaders, or rewriting history to suit colonial agendas. Some examples include

- Indigenous Inferiorization: José de Anchieta’s writings reflect this bias when describing an ally as *"so cultured that he could not be Brazilian,"* revealing a dismissive view of Indigenous peoples

- Genealogical Manipulation: Alberto L. Schneider’s research notes how Brazilian genealogists often obscured Indigenous ancestry, even when historical documents confirmed it—such as the case of Isabel Rodrigues, wife of Antônio Bicudo, described as a "native of Brazil"

- Historical Distortion: Rewriting history was not limited to Pindorama (modern-day Brazil). Dr. Robert Barker suggests that the twelve Inca generations may have been inspired by the twelve tribes of Israel, while Dr. Philomena Gebran notes the appropriation of Jesus Christ’s figure, reimagining him as "a son of an Inca"

source.text: Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, pp. 89

common.text:
#### The Indigenous Family

Frederick Engels, building on the research of Lewis Henry Morgan, described Indigenous family structures as follows

• "The study of the history of the family dates from [...]"
    • "[...] the peculiar system of kinship prevailing among the Iroquis was common among all the aborigenes of the United States and was thus spread over a whole continent [...]"
  • "[...] the gens, organized according to mother right, was the original form out of which developed the later gens, organized according to father right, the gens as we find it among the civilized people of antiquity."

Since Morgan’s conclusions (cited by Engels) emerged after colonization—a period when Europeans often misunderstood Indigenous family systems—many historical chronicles and genealogical records contain inaccuracies

history.text: Figure 6: Map of Asia highlighting regions referenced in genetic studies, showing populations with analyzed haplogroups. Siberian boundaries based on Britannica Encyclopedia (Editors of Britanica Enciclopedia ). © Mapswire (Mapswire).
history.imgdesc: This figure emphasizes Russian territories stretching from the Ural Mountains to the Bering Strait (collectively known as Siberia), with particular focus on the Altai region near the borders of Mongolia, China, and Kazakhstan. Mongolia, China, and the Koreas (North and South) are also highlighted.

history.text:
#### Family Considerations

Since writing systems developed millennia after migrations from Asia to Abya Yala (the Americas) and only in specific regions, identifying individuals from this distant era is impossible. Instead, we describe hypothetical couples—unnamed but genetically inferred—based on available research

As this is an introductory text, we focus only on major haplogroups, omitting subgroups (detailed in cited papers).

Alongside biological analysis, we adopt a perspective of matrilineal family organization, consistent with many Indigenous traditions. In later sections relying on written records or external accounts, we follow the patriarchal frameworks presented in those sources

sources.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6

history.text: Individuals with this mitochondrial DNA belong to macro-haplogroup N, primarily found in western and central Siberia. Notably, subgroup A2 is prevalent near the Bering Strait

source.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6

history.text: The most frequent paternal lineage among Indigenous men in Abya Yala, the haplogroup Q

As the son of a man with haplogroup Q and a woman with haplogroup A, he inherits:
- Y chromosome from his father (Q).
- Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from his mother (A)

source.text: Dulik, Matthew C. et al., pp. 237
Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6

sources.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6, 7, 18

history.text: Individuals with this mitochondrial DNA belong to macro-haplogroup N, which is found in Siberia, Mongolia, China, and Korea

source.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6, 7, 18

history.text: The haplogroup Q is repeated, but this does not refer to the same individual who was believed to have married a woman with haplogroup A

As the son of a man with haplogroup Q and a woman with haplogroup B, he inherits:
- Y chromosome from his father (Q).
- Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from his mother (B)

source.text: Dulik, Matthew C. et al., pp. 237
Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 6, 7

sources.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 7, 8, 19

history.text: The haplogroup Q is repeated, but this does not refer to the same individual who was believed to have married a woman with haplogroup A or B

As the son of a man with haplogroup Q and a woman with haplogroup C, he inherits:
- Y chromosome from his father (Q).
- Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from his mother (C)

source.text: Dulik, Matthew C. et al., pp. 237
Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 7, 8

history.text: Individuals with this mitochondrial DNA belong to macro-haplogroup M, which is present in Siberia. The authors highlight the majority of the haplotypes of this haplogroup did not exhibit sub-haplogroup-specific mutations

source.text: Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 8, 19

history.text: The haplogroup C was tested in population from Abya Yala (American) south

As the daughter of a woman with haplogroup D, she inherits:
- Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from his mother (D)

source.text: Dulik, Matthew C. et al., pp. 237
Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 8

history.text: The haplogroups "A-D" are the majority of the haplogroups found in the Abya Yala (America) continent, but they are not the unique. It was also found a X mtDNA, found actually in Europe, and traces of it found in Altai
The haplogroup Q is repeated, but this does not refer to the same individual who was believed to have married a woman with haplogroup A, B, or C

As the daughter of a woman with haplogroup X, she inherits:
- Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) from his mother (X)

source.text: Dulik, Matthew C. et al., pp. 237
Starikovskaya, Elena B. et. al., pp. 8

exercise_v2.question: A origem dos povos indígenas de Abya Yala (América) entre 30.000 e 13.000 anos é o Oriente Médio?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Os dados genéticos dos haplogrupos (cromossomo Y e mtDNA) mostram que os indígenas são originários de diferentes regiões da Ásia (Sibéria, Mongólia, China e Coréias), as quais não incluem o Oriente Médio, apesar da migração da África para o resto do mundo ter passador por lá há tempos ainda mais remotos.
